awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: ATD: Robust, Accurate and Efficient Graph-Structured RNN for Spatio-Temporal Forecasting and Anomaly Detection
awd_abstract_narration:
The project aims to develop robust, efficient, and transferrable deep learning algorithms for prediction and anomaly detection in human spatio-temporal dynamics. This will be a fundamental step in providing  reliable and speedy decision support for mitigating infectious diseases and countering threats in a time varying and spatially complex environment.  The project shall advance recent computational tools (deep neural networks) in adversarial conditions and on resource limited (low cost, low energy) platform, thereby contribute to information technology in adversarial learning, mobile computing and effective decision making. A broad range of applications include threat detection and prediction for traffic and public transportation networks, security and privacy critical data analysis and prediction, threat detection and error correction for hydraulic, electrical and nuclear power systems.  

The approaches to be used involve novel techniques in high dimensional non-smooth non-convex optimization and graph representation. Specifically, the project shall study (1) multi-scale graph-structured recurrent neural networks for spatio-temporal data modeling, prediction and anomaly detection;  (2) adversarially robust, accurate, and transferable deep learning algorithms based on advection-diffusion equations; (3)  efficient quantization algorithms under adversarial conditions to reduce the latency of deep networks. The projects shall train a diverse body of graduate and undergraduate students at the Irvine and Los Angeles campuses of University of California through collaborative education and research activities in applied mathematics, computer science, data science and social science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project developed graph-structured recurrent neural networks and transformers on  spatio-temporal data sets for prediction and dynamic modeling, as well as robustness under adversarial attacks. Robustness leads to large size models for which complexity reduction techniques such as channel pruning and quantization have been studied for efficiency. The project also made use of mathematical and physical principles to complement purely data driven neural networks, for example Feynman-Kac formalism, SIR epidemic ordinary differential equation models. The project produced new algorithms with convergence guarantee and deepened theoretical understanding of empirically designed algorithms. The widely used binary-connect algorithm for weight quantization of neural networks is found to have oscillatory or recurrent behavior around a minimum of training loss function, which is proved rigorously in simplified settings and supported by computational experiments on deep networks. The project discovered geometric characterizations of slow to fast weight evolution in neural network training for classifying linearly non-separable data, and gave a mathematical justification for shallow networks with computational evidence in deep networks.  


The data-driven computational tools developed in the project are applied successfully to modeling and prediction of case counts during infectious disease outbreaks such as Covid 19 and leishmanisis, as well as voltage prediction in electrical power grid soon after a fault (e.g. a short circuit or power line failure) occurs.  In the power grid case, our efficent graph-structured transformer autoencoder, so called Glassoformer, outperforms existing benchmark methods and generates real-time prediction of voltage responses, several orders of magnitudes faster than direct   simulations of classical circuit equations. The computational tools in the project are potentially impactful to spatio-temporal forecasting problems in solar energy, vector-borne infectious diseases (dengue, zika), climate, social, economic and financial time series.
